Extremely long 18xx with a lot of trains to buy. After more than a dozen games I think I've had enough and no longer want to play it anymore as I still don't feel like I have any control of the game whatsoever. The winner will often be a player who gets two or three companies and runs one that frequently withholds and stays in the yellow part of the stock market while the other runs for dividends. This is sometimes hard to arrange and hard to stop someone who has successfully started doing so in the 4+ hours you have left to play before they win. The last two hours of this game are the hardest as you're tired after playing 6+ hours but this is when you need the most brain power to figure out how to lay your brown tiles, make your destination runs, and make your destination markers pay off the best. The tile manifest seems maddeningly insufficient for the game. I do like redeeming shares that you reissue later to help raise funds for bigger trains and price protection but otherwise I'd rather play other 18xx titles that are shorter or have a better payoff for the amount of time it takes to play like 2038. Or I'll play 18c2c which is based off of this game but is more about pairing up good companies.

Out of all the 18XX-variants I've played (of which few are modern), 1870 is by a clear margin the most interesting strategically, because there are so many options and possibilities, both early on and later in the game. In my experience there's little reason to play any other 18XX, except if you play 1870 sufficiently enough for it to be nice with some variation. I'm curious to look into if there's any newer or modern 18XX that are in fact better than 1870.

One of the classics with great replay value, but it can take very long compared to other 18xx titles.

I own the Rails on Board Wooden Station upgrade set.

This is a game of subtleties and razor thin balance. Unlike most recent, popular 18xx games that feature sledgehammer macguffins, 1870 takes a ton of plays to fuly understand the systems in place that govern good play (price protection! Getting a proper set up for a yellow company [different, in practice, than just trashing stock into yellow]! Maintaining destination runs! Burning through the enormous train roster!). The timing game here is subtle, and the tools that govern positional differences are suprisingly opaque. It's possible to win with any starting corporation. Price protection can throw a game as easily as it can win it. Understanding why the sharks who love this game will consistently dumpster you is quite a bit harder to understand than in 1830 or its other derivatives.

I'm not convinced it's "more fun" than more standard full cap games, but it is extremely obvious I need (many, many) more plays to form an informed opinion.

EDIT: Yes, this is absolutely a top tier 18xx.
